docs.lead_paragraph: Are you filled with dread instead of delight about the arrival of spring, anticipating the sneezes, runny nose and itchy eyes that are the hallmarks of seasonal allergic rhinitis? Well, suffer no more. There is now a wide array of treatments, over the counter and prescription, that can suppress the annoying symptoms of spring (and fall) allergies, which can interfere with sleep, work and enjoyment of life and increase your vulnerability to colds, sinusitis and other respiratory infections. You are hardly alone. Ten to 30 percent of Americans are allergic to wind-swept pollen from trees, grasses, weeds and/or molds. In spring, you can blame such trees as alder, ash, birch, cedar, elm, hazel, maple, oak, olive, pecan, sycamore and walnut. In summer, common allergens include grasses like timothy, ryegrass, Bermuda grass, English plantain and sheep sorrel. And, of course, there's fall, with pollen from ragweed, sage and Russian thistle the common culprits.

headline.main: Breaking the Cycle of Seasonal Sneezes

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on prospects for breaking cycle of seasonal allergies, and the attendant sneezes, runny nose and itchy eyes; comments on the allergic response, prevention and treatment; comments on nasal sprays, antihistamines, decongestants and immunotherapy; chart shows allergy seasons (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With the voices inside her head ordering her to kill, Lisa Duy walked into Doug's Shoot'n Sports here to buy a Smith & Wesson 9-millimeter semiautomatic pistol. For Doug's, the biggest gun store in Utah, the transaction was routine. The manager, Dave Larsen, called the Utah Bureau of Criminal Identification to run a background check on Ms. Duy, and the agency quickly approved the sale, having found no record of felony convictions or mental illness. In the basement shooting range, Mr. Larsen showed Ms. Duy, 24 and unemployed, how to hold and fire the heavy stainless-steel gun. The only thing unusual, he thought, was that as she left the store, headed for the bus stop outside, she was wearing the shooting-range ear protectors he had lent her.

headline.main: Hole in Gun Control Law Lets Mentally Ill Through

docs.abstract: Third article in four-part series, Rampage Killers, focuses on difficulty of keeping guns out of hands of people with serious mental problems; gun background checks of people with psychiatric problems typically fail to turn up mental health history despite key provision of nation's gun control law that prohibits people involuntarily committed to mental institutions from buying handguns; laws in most states guard privacy of mentally ill and generally bar law-enforcement agencies from access to records in effort to protect them from stigma; loophole is contributing factor to wave of school and workplace shootings in past decade that have fueled growing debate pitting public-safety concerns against rights of mentally ill; chart; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: They are not drunk or high on drugs. They are not racists or Satanists, or addicted to violent video games, movies or music. Most are white men, but a surprising number are women, Asians and blacks. Many have college degrees, but most are unemployed. Many are military veterans.
